unnormalised: I remember the first time I truly understood the sheer volume of numbers involved in retail – it was during Diwali, back in '18. My family runs a small saree shop in Surat, “Radha Textiles,” and Diwali is, as you can imagine, our Super Bowl.
normalised: I remember the first time I truly understood the sheer volume of numbers involved in retail – it was during Diwali, back in two thousand eighteen. My family runs a small saree shop in Surat, “Radha Textiles,” and Diwali is, as you can imagine, our Super Bowl.

unnormalised: Leading up to Diwali, we started prepping sometime in Oct. Ordering new stock meant dealing with invoices worth ₹2.5 lakhs, figuring out which designs would sell, and estimating demand. My dad, he's old school. He uses these huge ledgers, you know, with numbers scrawled all over them. I tried to get him to use a spreadsheet once, showed him how Excel could do the calculations in like, 2 seconds, but he just chuckled and said, "Beta, my brain is the best computer. Been using it for 40+ years!"

unnormalised: That year, we’d ordered around 500+ sarees, each priced differently depending on the material and design. Silk sarees ranged from Rs. 5000 to Rs. 25000 a piece! Cotton sarees were more affordable, starting at around Rs. 800. We even had a special "Diwali Dhamaka" sale, offering a flat 15% off on selected items.
normalised: That year, we’d ordered around five hundred plus sarees, each priced differently depending on the material and design. Silk sarees ranged from rupees five thousand to rupees twenty five thousand a piece! Cotton sarees were more affordable, starting at around rupees eight hundred. We even had a special "Diwali Dhamaka" sale, offering a flat fifteen percent off on selected items.

unnormalised: On the day of Diwali itself, the shop was packed. People were buying sarees, suits, and everything in between. Our cash register was ringing non-stop. By the end of the day, we had sold roughly 300 sarees and generated a revenue of around ₹7 lakhs. It was insane!
normalised: On the day of Diwali itself, the shop was packed. People were buying sarees, suits, and everything in between. Our cash register was ringing non-stop. By the end of the day, we had sold roughly three hundred sarees and generated a revenue of around rupee seven lakhs. It was insane!

unnormalised: I remember my cousin, Rohan, who was helping out that day, kept track of the sales using a small calculator. He punched in numbers after numbers. By 10 PM, he was half-asleep, but still diligently recording every transaction. He’d mutter things like, “Another customer bought 2 sarees for ₹6,800…next!”
normalised: I remember my cousin, Rohan, who was helping out that day, kept track of the sales using a small calculator. He punched in numbers after numbers. By ten P-M, he was half-asleep, but still diligently recording every transaction. He’d mutter things like, “Another customer bought two sarees for rupees six thousand eight hundred…next!”

unnormalised: After closing, we all sat down to tally up the final numbers. It took us hours. We compared the cash in hand with the sales records, checked the credit card transactions (around 20% of our sales were through card), and accounted for the discounts we had given. The final profit margin, after deducting all expenses, came to around 22%, which was pretty good.

unnormalised: That Diwali, I realized that retail isn't just about selling clothes; it's a game of numbers. It’s about margins, percentages, discounts, and inventory. It's about predicting demand, managing expenses, and maximizing profits. It's a constant balancing act. So yeah, next time you see a Diwali sale with "Upto 50% off!", just know there's a whole lot of calculation that goes on behind the scenes! And a lot of late nights.
